musicalLanguage.description: The Peruvian Andean folk melody, composed in 1913 and later popularized internationally, is built on the pentatonic scale that gives it its distinctive soaring quality. The melody evokes the flight of a condor over the Andes — wide intervals and open voicings create a sense of vast space. The arrangement uses the E minor pentatonic scale throughout, keeping the authentic Andean sound.
musicalLanguage.structure: A section: pentatonic melody over Em-G (4 bars), B section: ascending climax over Am-Em (4 bars)
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: The opening pentatonic melody — instantly recognizable, soaring and open.
Bar 5: The melody reaches its highest point — the condor at its peak.
Bars 7-8: The gentle descent — the condor gliding back down.
teachingGoals: Pentatonic scale — the foundation of folk music worldwide
Wide intervals and open voicings to create spacious sound
Connecting Andean folk tradition to piano technique
styleTips: Think of wide open spaces — the Andes mountains. Let notes ring.
The melody should soar — use legato and sustain pedal generously
Left hand should be sparse and open — fifths and octaves, not dense chords

measures.teachingNote: Em pentatonic — ascending. Open and airy. The condor takes flight.
G major — melody peaks on D5 and descends. Wide and free.
Em — climbing again. Each ascent reaches a little higher.
Am — the peak at E5. Wide descending interval. Majestic.
Em — the soaring passage. The condor at its highest. Full tone.
G major — beginning the descent. Still graceful, still open.
Am to Em — gliding lower. The melody settles.
Em — home. Whole note E. The condor has landed.
